title: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited - Yangon Branch provides MMK 3 billion loan to Acleda MFI Myanmar Co., Ltd. for unspecified purposes
description: On December 11, 2017, Acleda MFI Myanmar Co., Ltd., one of Acleda Bank Plc.'s subsidiaries, entered into a MMK 3,000,000,000 loan agreement for a line of credit with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited - Yangon Branch. The full MMK 3 billion was drawn down on December 20, 2017. The maturity date is December 20, 2020, which gives a 3 year maturity. The loan was to be repaid in six semi annual installments starting from June 20, 2018 (giving a grace period of 0.5 years), and its purpose was not specified.
staff_comments: AidData has inferred the commitment year to be 2017, as this loan is not in the 2016 Annual Report produced by Acleda Bank.
combined_text:
# Sector

The full MMK 3 billion was drawn down on December 20, 2017. The maturity date is December 20, 2020, which gives a 3 year maturity. The loan was to be repaid in six semi annual installments starting from June 20, 2018 (giving a grace period of 0.5 years), and its purpose was not specified.

evidence: MMK 3 billion loan for unspecified purposes, banking and financial services sector

title: CTIEC provides $48 million supplier credit — via EPC+F arrangement — for Phase 1 of 220 MW Minbu Solar Power Plant Project
description: On December 15, 2017, China Triumph International Engineering Company Limited (CTIEC) issued a $48 million supplier credit (loan) — as part of a larger Sinosure-backed EPC+F (EPCF) arrangement — to GEP (Myanmar) Co., Ltd. (GEPM) for Phase 1 of the 220 MW Minbu Solar Power Plant Project. GEPM is a special purpose vehicle (SPV) and wholly-owned subsidiary of Green Earth Power (Thailand) Co., Ltd. (GEPT). The loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 2.25-year grace period, and a 13.79-year maturity, and a 6% interest rate. The first repayment date was originally scheduled for February 28, 2020 and the last repayment was originally scheduled for September 27, 2031 (12 years after Phase 1 achieved its Commercial Operations Date). However, the first repayment date was later changed to October 31, 2020.    The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance 70% of the cost of a $66.31 million commercial (supply) contract between Vintage EPC Co., Ltd. (VEPC) and CTIEC, which was signed on August 3, 2016 and amended on December 21, 2017. The purpose of Phase 1 of the project was to install 50MW of power generation capacity at the Minbu solar farm in Minbu District (exact locational coordinates: 20.0494, 94.6828). In February 2016, GEPT incorporated GEPM as a project company (SPV) to develop the 220 MW Minbu Solar Power Plant Project. Then, in March 2016, GEPM executed a Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with Myanmar Electric Power Enterprise — later renamed Electric Power Generation Enterprise (EPGE) — for a BOT (Built-Operate-Transfer) concession with a term of 30 years. On August 4, 2016, one day after the supply contract for the project was signed, VEPC and VTE International Construction Co., Ltd. (VINTER) entered into 4 turnkey EPC subcontracts with CTIEC for the 4 respective phases of the project.   Construction started in April 2018 and was originally expected to end within 12 months (April 2019). Construction was ultimately completed in June 2019.  Phase 1 included the construction works of all substations for Phases 2, 3, and 4 to connect to the transmission line of EPGE. On April 5, 2019, the Department of Power Transmission and System Control (DPTSC), under the authority of Myanmar’s Ministry of Electricity and Energy (MOEE), conducted the power plant’s cold commissioning. Supply of electricity to Myanmar National Grid started on June 27, 2019. The power plant started to realize revenue and achieved its Phase 1 Commercial Operation Date (COD) on September 27, 2019 under the 30-year PPA at a contractual electricity rate of USD 0.1275 per kWh. On November 15, 2019, EPGE and MOEE issued a letter of confirmation of the COD for Phase 1. The Provisional Acceptance Date for Phase 1 was on February 28, 2020. The Government of Myanmar announced a countrywide, Covid-19 lockdown from March 29, 2020 until August 31, 2020. It then extended the lockdown to October 31, 2020. Under Clause 17.1.2 of the supplier credit agreement, force majeure was invoked. Consequently, the loan’s first repayment date was moved to October 31, 2020.
staff_comments: 1. Under most EPC+F contractual arrangements, a loan is extended to the EPC contractor but with a sovereign guarantee from the host government. Therefore, AidData assumes that the loan issued to CTIEC is backed by a repayment guarantee from the Government of Myanmar (i.e. a sovereign guarantee). 2. The Chinese project title is 缅甸敏巫220MW地面光伏电站项目 or 建的缅甸敏巫220兆瓦地面光伏电站项目（一期. 3. More research is needed to determine the identity of the lending institution that financed Phases 2, 3, and 4 of the 220 MW Minbu Solar Power Plant Project. 4. As part of the EPC+F arrangement, one source suggsts that CTIEC secured financing from 'a financing company in China' (https://www.irplus.in.th/Listed/META/pdf/MDA_3Q2021N_EN.pdf). This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
CTIEC provides $48 million supplier credit — via EPC+F arrangement — for Phase 1 of 220 MW Minbu Solar Power Plant Project

# Description
On December 15, 2017, China Triumph International Engineering Company Limited (CTIEC) issued a $48 million supplier credit (loan) — as part of a larger Sinosure-backed EPC+F (EPCF) arrangement — to GEP (Myanmar) Co., Ltd. (GEPM) for Phase 1 of the 220 MW Minbu Solar Power Plant Project. GEPM is a special purpose vehicle (SPV) and wholly-owned subsidiary of Green Earth Power (Thailand) Co., Ltd. (GEPT). The loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 2.25-year grace period, and a 13.79-year maturity, and a 6% interest rate. The first repayment date was originally scheduled for February 28, 2020 and the last repayment was originally scheduled for September 27, 2031 (12 years after Phase 1 achieved its Commercial Operations Date). However, the first repayment date was later changed to October 31, 2020.    The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance 70% of the cost of a $66.31 million commercial (supply) contract between Vintage EPC Co., Ltd. (VEPC) and CTIEC, which was signed on August 3, 2016 and amended on December 21, 2017. The purpose of Phase 1 of the project was to install 50MW of power generation capacity at the Minbu solar farm in Minbu District (exact locational coordinates: 20.0494, 94.6828). In February 2016, GEPT incorporated GEPM as a project company (SPV) to develop the 220 MW Minbu Solar Power Plant Project. Then, in March 2016, GEPM executed a Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with Myanmar Electric Power Enterprise — later renamed Electric Power Generation Enterprise (EPGE) — for a BOT (Built-Operate-Transfer) concession with a term of 30 years. On August 4, 2016, one day after the supply contract for the project was signed, VEPC and VTE International Construction Co., Ltd. (VINTER) entered into 4 turnkey EPC subcontracts with CTIEC for the 4 respective phases of the project.   Construction started in April 2018 and was originally expected to end within 12 months (April 2019). Construction was ultimately completed in June 2019.  Phase 1 included the construction works of all substations for Phases 2, 3, and 4 to connect to the transmission line of EPGE. On April 5, 2019, the Department of Power Transmission and System Control (DPTSC), under the authority of Myanmar’s Ministry of Electricity and Energy (MOEE), conducted the power plant’s cold commissioning. Supply of electricity to Myanmar National Grid started on June 27, 2019. The power plant started to realize revenue and achieved its Phase 1 Commercial Operation Date (COD) on September 27, 2019 under the 30-year PPA at a contractual electricity rate of USD 0.1275 per kWh. On November 15, 2019, EPGE and MOEE issued a letter of confirmation of the COD for Phase 1. The Provisional Acceptance Date for Phase 1 was on February 28, 2020. The Government of Myanmar announced a countrywide, Covid-19 lockdown from March 29, 2020 until August 31, 2020. It then extended the lockdown to October 31, 2020. Under Clause 17.1.2 of the supplier credit agreement, force majeure was invoked. Consequently, the loan’s first repayment date was moved to October 31, 2020.
justification: Primary purpose is solar power generation with clear renewable energy focus
evidence: 220 MW solar power plant, solar farm development, connection to national grid, renewable energy focus

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 200 million grant — via August 2017 ETCA — for Phase 1 of Windhoek to Hosea Kutako International Airport Road Project (Linked to Project ID#60977, #92520, #60980)
description: On August 28, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Namibia signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an RMB 200 million (NAD 400 million) grant for Phase 1 of the Windhoek to Hosea Kutako International Airport Road Project. Phase 1 is a 8.4 kilometer, two-way, four-lane highway from Mandume Ndemufayo Avenue (or MR49 or Kupferburg road) to Sam Nujoma Drive. The Windhoek to Hosea Kutako International Airport Road Project is also called the TR 9/1 or Trunk Road 9/1 Project.    In early December 2015, a joint venture between China Railway Engineering Seventh Bureau (direct subsidiary of CREC) and Onamagongwa Trading Enterprises (see the linked Project ID#67851) won a NAD 799 million ($66.65 million or RMB 312.97 million) bid to implement the project. On December 16, 2015, a groundbreaking ceremony was held for the first phase of the project. Construction was scheduled to last 36 months between January 2016 and January 2019, but conflict between the JV partners led to significant delays. As of December 2019, the project had achieved a 77% completion rate, and so this project is in the implementation stage.  As of November 15, 2021, the CEO of the Roads Authority (RA) announced that the project had achieved a 98% completion rate.  China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) reportedly issued an RMB 447,000,000 grant (captured via Project ID #92520) to support Phase 2B of this same road project. Also in 2018, China Eximbank signed a loan agreement (captured via Project ID#60977) for Phase 2B.
staff_comments: 1. The China Eximbank funding for both Phase 1 and Phase 2B of this project is captured in Umbrella Project ID#60980.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 200 million grant — via August 2017 ETCA — for Phase 1 of Windhoek to Hosea Kutako International Airport Road Project (Linked to Project ID#60977, #92520, #60980)

# Description
On August 28, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Namibia signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an RMB 200 million (NAD 400 million) grant for Phase 1 of the Windhoek to Hosea Kutako International Airport Road Project. Phase 1 is a 8.4 kilometer, two-way, four-lane highway from Mandume Ndemufayo Avenue (or MR49 or Kupferburg road) to Sam Nujoma Drive. The Windhoek to Hosea Kutako International Airport Road Project is also called the TR 9/1 or Trunk Road 9/1 Project.    In early December 2015, a joint venture between China Railway Engineering Seventh Bureau (direct subsidiary of CREC) and Onamagongwa Trading Enterprises (see the linked Project ID#67851) won a NAD 799 million ($66.65 million or RMB 312.97 million) bid to implement the project. On December 16, 2015, a groundbreaking ceremony was held for the first phase of the project. Construction was scheduled to last 36 months between January 2016 and January 2019, but conflict between the JV partners led to significant delays. As of December 2019, the project had achieved a 77% completion rate, and so this project is in the implementation stage.  As of November 15, 2021, the CEO of the Roads Authority (RA) announced that the project had achieved a 98% completion rate.  China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) reportedly issued an RMB 447,000,000 grant (captured via Project ID #92520) to support Phase 2B of this same road project. Also in 2018, China Eximbank signed a loan agreement (captured via Project ID#60977) for Phase 2B.
justification: Road construction project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 8.4 kilometer highway construction, general transportation infrastructure

title: China Donates Wildlife Protection Equipment worth 15 million NAD to Namibia
description: On 15 May 2017, the Chinese Government granted wildlife protection equipment worth 15 million NAD to Namibia. The donation includes: 30 pickup vehicles, 500 tents, 600 moisture proof pads, 600 sleeping bags, 100 binoculars, 100 solar power batteries, and 1000 mosquito nets. The donation will be used by anti-poaching law enforcement units supporting conservation efforts in Namibia.  This donation is in response to then recent evidence of Chinese nationals poaching Namibia's rhinos and elephants to sell their ivory.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China Donates Wildlife Protection Equipment worth 15 million NAD to Namibia

# Description
On 15 May 2017, the Chinese Government granted wildlife protection equipment worth 15 million NAD to Namibia. The donation includes: 30 pickup vehicles, 500 tents, 600 moisture proof pads, 600 sleeping bags, 100 binoculars, 100 solar power batteries, and 1000 mosquito nets. The donation will be used by anti-poaching law enforcement units supporting conservation efforts in Namibia.  This donation is in response to then recent evidence of Chinese nationals poaching Namibia's rhinos and elephants to sell their ivory.
justification: Project focuses on wildlife protection and conservation efforts without direct energy or environmental transition impacts
evidence: Donation of equipment for anti-poaching units, focus on conservation and law enforcement

title: China Donates 2,600 tons of Rice to Namibia (Linked to #52331)
description: On 18 April 2017, government officials signed an exchange of letters in which China pledged to donate 2,600 tons of rice to Namibia throughout 2017 in response to drought-induced food shortages. The donation worth about N$40 million in Namibian dollars was completed by June 2017.  The first rice donation from China to Namibia, in 2016, is captured in project #52331.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
China Donates 2,600 tons of Rice to Namibia (Linked to #52331)

# Description
On 18 April 2017, government officials signed an exchange of letters in which China pledged to donate 2,600 tons of rice to Namibia throughout 2017 in response to drought-induced food shortages. The donation worth about N$40 million in Namibian dollars was completed by June 2017.  The first rice donation from China to Namibia, in 2016, is captured in project #52331.
justification: Project is focused on food aid and addressing food security, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 2,600 tons of rice to address drought-induced food shortages, humanitarian focus

title: China Donates 20 Sewing Machines to Charity in Kavango West, Namibia
description: On 21 December 2017, the Chinese Embassy in Namibia officially donated 20 sewing machines to the Kavango West Provincial Government. The donation was then given to an unnamed charity organization supporting working women in rural areas of Kavango West. The value of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China Donates 20 Sewing Machines to Charity in Kavango West, Namibia

# Description
On 21 December 2017, the Chinese Embassy in Namibia officially donated 20 sewing machines to the Kavango West Provincial Government. The donation was then given to an unnamed charity organization supporting working women in rural areas of Kavango West. The value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project is a donation of sewing machines to support working women in rural areas, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 20 sewing machines to charity organization supporting working women in rural areas

title: China Henan International (CHICO) Donates to Okondjatu Community in Namibia
description: In 2017, China Henan International Cooperation Group (CHICO) financed and constructed three classrooms for Okondjatu Combined School, as well as two houses for the elderly care in Otjozondijupa Province. The official completion ceremony took place on 16 June 2017. The value of this donation and construction start date are unknown.

The official completion ceremony took place on 16 June 2017. The value of this donation and construction start date are unknown.
justification: Project focuses on social infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts

title: Chinese Ambassador Scholarship Fund Grants 330,096 NAD to Highline Secondary Students (Linked to Umbrella Project #62617)
description: On 15 June 2017, the Chinese Ambassador Scholarship Fund (umbrella project #62617) awarded 11 students from Highline Secondary School with a total of 330,096 NAD (24,500 NAD each) to support their outstanding academic careers.
